After the battle of Thapsus (April 6, Rc. 46) he received his lise frorn Caesar, but without permission to return to Rome. His brothers and friends, Cicero in particular, for some time exerted themselves in vain to procure this for him. It was not unnatural that the conqueror should let those obstinate foes wait for their pardon‚ who had kept him waiting so long for their submission ¹. Finassy, on September 23. 46, the Dic- tator gave an audience to the intercessors. The brothers and relatives fell at his feet3 Cicero spoke for them. Tubero the younger preferred against Ligarius a charge of perduellio or high treason, under a somewhat antiquated statute, in the Dictator's court.

ξ 4. The indictment showed that the defendant, by persevering in arms even after -the death of Pompeius, had taken the side of Juba a foreign prince against the Roman people ³. Caesar sat in the Forum, after the manner of the ancient kings, whose supreme jurisdiction he now assumed ¹. Such offences were usually tried before the quaestio perpetua de maiestate ; but at this time, as it appears from Suetonius ⁵, there was no praetor in existence to preside in that court. No other merely technical reason can be assigned for the choice of process made by the accuser. It is evident from ξ 13 of the speech that the sentence he asked was one of continued exile, not the death penalty, which the full rigour of the law allowed: but the fact that the defendant could not appear to plead his cause might well entitle him to this much consideration.
